hints.content: Start by understanding the definition of the h-index. It is the maximum value of h such that the researcher has published at least h papers that have each been cited at least h times.
Notice that the input array `citations` is sorted in non-descending order. This property can be leveraged to find the h-index efficiently.
Think about how you can use binary search to find the h-index. You want to determine the largest index where the number of citations is at least as large as the corresponding index value.
Define the search space for binary search. You can start with `left` at 0 and `right` at the length of the citations array, which will help you narrow down the possible values of h.

In your binary search, calculate the middle index `mid`. The condition to check is whether the citations at `mid` are greater than or equal to the number of papers that would correspond to that index (i.e., `n - mid`).

Remember that if `citations[mid]` is greater than or equal to `n - mid`, it means that you have found a potential h-index, but you should continue searching to the left to see if there's a higher valid h-index.
If `citations[mid]` is less than `n - mid`, you need to search to the right because it indicates that the current `mid` cannot be a valid h-index.
Keep track of the maximum valid h-index found during your binary search. This will be the value you return at the end of your search.
Consider edge cases, such as when all citations are zero or when the citations array has only one element. How will these cases affect the h-index calculation?
Finally, implement the binary search logic and ensure that you return the correct h-index after the search completes. Remember to handle the case where no valid h-index is found.

questionNotes: Citations array is sorted in non-descending order.
The output should be the maximum h-index value.
Consider edge cases like all citations being zero or only one paper.
